title: U.S. Markets Farm Goods to Nations Beyond China
summary: Trade war has sapped demand from a top buyer of U.S. crops and meat. The U.S. government is marketing the nation's crops and meat in smaller countries as Washington and Beijing continue to spar over trade.

title: Trump's Call to Leave Syria Draws Fire From GOP Allies
summary: Supporters warn that letting Turkey attack the Kurds and walking away from the fight against Islamic State would cause irreparable damage to U.S. interests. President Trump's latest move to end U.S. involvement in Syria drew a burst of condemnation from dedicated supporters, who warned that abandoning a key ally, the Kurds, and walking away from the fight against Islamic State would cause irreparable damage to U.S. interests.

title: U.S. Stocks Tick Lower as Investors Await Trade Developments
summary: As the week progresses, traders will be keeping eyes on headlines from Washington. Stocks inched lower, weighed down by shares of consumer-staples companies.

title: Group Nine to Acquire PopSugar in Latest Wave of Digital Media Tie-Ups
summary: All-stock deal values women-focused publisher PopSugar at $300 million; follows recent acquisitions involving Vox Media, Vice Media. Discovery Inc. -backed digital publisher Group Nine Media Inc. has agreed to acquire women-focused publisher PopSugar, the companies said, the latest merger of new-media firms hoping that greater scale will help them sell online ads, where Facebook and Google dominate.

title: Supreme Court Opens Term With Look at Effort to Bar Insanity Defense
summary: Several justices balk at seeing historical rights of defendants reduced; less-than-unanimous convictions also on docket. WASHINGTON-The Supreme Court opened its term Monday with arguments exploring fundamental questions of criminal law, hearing separate cases asking whether the Constitution permits states to abolish the insanity defense or convict defendants absent a unanimous jury.

title: Meat, Milk Producers Seek to Defend Supermarket Turf
summary: Dairy, beef products fight for shelf space with plant-based alternatives. Dairies and ranchers want to push plant-based alternatives off their turf.

title: NBA's China Flap Highlights High-Wire Act for American Firms
summary: Global companies from Marriott to Gap have come under fire for taking a perceived stance on Hong Kong protests. The National Basketball Association became the latest American business to face criticism after inflaming Chinese sensitivities, underscoring the dilemma for Western brands as China moves toward overtaking the U.S. as the world's largest consumer market.

title: With Friends Like the U.S.
summary: The Kurds helped to defeat ISIS. Trump leaves them to Erdogan.. President Trump's defeat of Islamic State as a territorial power was a major foreign-policy success, yet he may now undo it with a retreat from Syria that will also signal to U.S. allies that the White House can't be trusted.

title: Got Oxygen?
summary: A Nobel for finding a molecular switch with huge medical benefits.. Why do elite athletes get better by training at high altitudes and how do cancer tumors develop their own blood supply? The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine on Monday was awarded to Americans William Kaelin Jr. and Gregg Semenza and Sir Peter Ratcliffe of Britain for their groundbreaking research that helps answer these and other questions behind many medical breakthroughs.

title: The Supreme Court's Sex Debate
summary: Congress is the place to rewrite laws as social mores change.. If you hadn't heard, conservatives on the Supreme Court are preparing an all-out attack on America's marginalized classes. The blitz begins Tuesday with a trio of cases that consider whether gay and transgender people are protected against employment discrimination under the Civil Rights Act. The Justices should focus on the law, not these overwrought political claims.

title: The FBI Is Lucky to Have William Barr
summary: Agents in the field during his first stint as attorney general had nothing but praise: 'He knows no fear.'. Attorney General William Barr has come under harsh attack from Democrats, the media and former officials such as John Brennan, who ran the Central Intelligence Agency under Barack Obama. I served during Mr. Barr's first stint as attorney general from 1991-93 and am glad he's back. The bureau was let down by poor leadership under former Director James Comey. It was led down a rabbit hole into a baseless investigation of a presidential campaign, and its reputation has been tarnished by headquarters sycophants. Mr. Barr has the character and experience to get the bureau back on track.

title: America Needs Dialogue With Moscow
summary: Sanctions have their place, but some of them are undermining trust without serving their purpose.. When I served as U.S. ambassador to Russia, the embassy in Moscow held a regular safety exercise called the "duck and cover drill." The drill is designed to save lives in the event of an attack, and our team practiced it so often that even embassy children could recite the announcement by heart. Through repetition, our reaction to the jarring siren became an ordinary part of the job.

title: Trump's Jacksonian Syria Withdrawal
summary: He isn't the first president to try to pull America back from the Middle East.. Under investigation for impeachment he may be, but President Trump can still shake the world with his tweets. Explaining his decision to pull U.S. troops away from the Turkish-Syrian border at the cost of the Kurdish-led Syrian Democratic Forces, and open the way for Turkish forces to create what Ankara calls a "safety zone," President Trump tweeted early Monday that "it is time for us to get out of these ridiculous Endless Wars, many of them tribal, and bring our soldiers home."

title: Impeaching Trump Voters
summary: It's revenge for 2016, and nervousness about Democratic prospects for 2020.. For the sake of argument, let's stipulate that Donald Trump is everything Democrats say he is: a president who abuses his national-security powers by siccing a foreign government on his political rival, a racist/bigot/nativist constantly using "dog whistles" to stoke division, a man uniquely unfit to sit in the Oval Office.

title: Justice Ginsburg, a Woman Isn't a 'Demiboy'
summary: If the Supreme Court redefines 'sex' to include 'gender identity,' the female sex will suffer.. Should the legal meaning of "sex" be changed? That's what the Supreme Court will consider Tuesday when it hears oral arguments in the cases of Harris Funeral Homes v. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission and Bostock v. Clayton County. Should the justices decide to broaden the meaning of sex, it would spell disaster for women.

title: Houston, We Have a China Problem
summary: The NBA kowtows after the Rockets general manager fails to toe the Communist Party line.. China has become comfortable pushing around American companies-a little too comfortable. Its boycott of the National Basketball Association's Houston Rockets, announced Sunday to muzzle support for mass protests in Hong Kong, has alerted Americans to the threat posed by China's bullying in a way that intellectual-property theft never could.

summary: 'I think in this day and age, you really do have to stand for something,' said Commissioner Adam Silver.. From "The NBA is not afraid to lead on social justice," CNN.com, Feb. 19, 2018:

title: New York City Boosts Homeless Outreach After Four Men Are Killed
summary: Three of four homeless men beaten to death in Chinatown over the weekend are identified. New York City will increase its mental-health outreach to the homeless in Manhattan's Chinatown after four homeless men were bludgeoned to death in the neighborhood, Mayor Bill de Blasio said Monday.

title: 'Stalin and the Fate of Europe' Review: As the Curtain Came Down
summary: Surprisingly, at certain flashpoints in postwar Europe the Soviet Union aimed at accommodation more than outright conflict.. Of the many events that took place in the final phase of World War II, the activities on the small Danish island of Bornholm are among the least remembered. On May 9, 1945, just as Germany was surrendering to the Allies, the Red Army occupied Bornholm. The island's strategic location 150 miles northeast of the German city of Lubeck could have given the Soviets control of the route between the Baltic and North seas, creating leverage for the Kremlin in any postwar settlement. And a Soviet presence there fed Stalin's hope of imposing Soviet-Danish cooperation, both political and economic.

title: Appeals Court Stays Order That Trump Release Tax Returns
summary: Judge rules President Trump isn't immune from criminal investigations while in office; appeals court blocks immediate enforcement of subpoena. A federal judge in New York on Monday ruled President Trump's accounting firm must turn over eight years of his personal and business tax returns, an order that was immediately put on hold by an appeals court.

title: Pentagon, White House Budget Office Get Ukraine Subpoenas
summary: The demand for documents by House committees mark the latest in the impeachment inquiry. WASHINGTON-House committees subpoenaed the Pentagon and White House budget office for documents related to the Trump administration's dealings with Ukraine, the latest effort by Democrats to obtain new information from the administration on efforts to pressure Kyiv to investigate the president's political rival Joe Biden.

title: New York City Lawmakers Look to Regulate Facial-Recognition Tools

summary: Yields snap a seven-session streak of declines. U.S. government bond yields crept higher Monday, snapping a seven-session streak of declines.

summary: After a much lauded off-Broadway run, Jeremy O. Harris's play about sex and race moves to the Great White Way.. New York

title: Nobel Prize in Medicine Awarded to U.S. and British Scientists
summary: Americans William Kaelin and Gregg Semenza shared the prize with Peter Ratcliffe of the U.K.. A trio of U.S. and British scientists won this year's Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for discovering how cells sense and adapt to the amount of oxygen available-findings that open the door to new ways of tackling anemia and cancer, among other diseases.

title: Cargill Executive Urges Resolution of U.S.-China Trade Dispute
summary: Company's sustainability chief warns of effect on U.S. farmers and environment if soy production shifts to South America. summary: As bipartisan criticism greets Trump move, Senate majority leader cautions against 'retreat'. The U.S. Soccer Federation, defending itself against a gender discrimination suit from the U.S. women's soccer team, last week submitted court filings asserting that four U.S. women's national team players were paid more than the highest-earning player on the U.S. men's team over a period of about six years.

summary: Resume Subscription. President Trump's decision to step out of the way of a Turkish offensive in northern Syria renews pressure on the Kurdish ethnic group and the forces that helped it establish a semiautonomous region in the country.

summary: Crude pares earlier gains as a stronger dollar makes commodities more expensive for overseas buyers. Oil prices edged lower Monday, erasing an earlier gain as the dollar rose and investors looked ahead to another round of trade talks between the U.S. and China.

title: Iraq Acts to End Deadly Response to Protests
summary: Government pledges new social aid in a bid to calm antigovernment that have threatened a new cycle of violence. BAGHDAD-Iraqi leaders moved Monday to stop the use of deadly force against protesters and promised new social aid in a bid to calm demonstrations that have threatened a new cycle of violence.

title: Bonobos Trims Jobs as Owner Walmart Seeks to Cut E-commerce Losses
summary: The men's apparel retailer to eliminate several dozen positions. Bonobos, the men's apparel retailer owned by Walmart Inc . , is laying off some staff on Monday as Walmart works to narrow losses in its unprofitable U.S. e-commerce division.

title: Biden in Search of an Argument
summary: His Washington Post op-ed offers a revealing look at his campaign and the impeachment drama.. If Joe Biden had a reasonable explanation for his family's lucrative ventures in countries where he was leading U.S. policy as Vice President, he likely would have shared it in a Washington Post op-ed. Perhaps more alarming for Democrats-whether or not they favor Mr. Biden for the party's 2020 presidential nomination-is his inability to make a concrete case for President Donald Trump's impeachment. It seems that Mr. Biden is not alone.

title: Envoy Volker Steps Down as Head of McCain Institute
summary: Diplomat was questioned in impeachment inquiry over his role arranging Giuliani meeting. WASHINGTON-Kurt Volker, who stepped down last month as U.S. special envoy to Ukraine as Democrats probed his role in President Trump's interactions with Kyiv, said on Monday that he would resign as the executive director of the McCain Institute, a Washington think tank affiliated with Arizona State University.

title: NBCUniversal Appoints Content Chief, New Boss for Streaming Service
summary: Bonnie Hammer to lead newly created TV-production business; Matt Strauss to head Peacock. Comcast Corp.'s NBCUniversal has consolidated its TV-production business and named a new head of its soon-to-be launched streaming service as part of a broad realignment of its entertainment operations, the company said Monday.

title: The NBA Responded. U.S. Politicians Roared. Now It's China's Move.
summary: The league is struggling to balance its economic ambitions in China against American democratic norms as it navigates the fallout of Rockets general manager Daryl Morey's pro-Hong Kong tweet. The NBA is resisting Beijing's pressure to punish a Houston Rockets executive who publicly supported protesters in Hong Kong amid a political furor in the U.S. as the league struggled to balance its economic ambitions in China against American democratic norms.

title: Fix, Leave Alone or Close the Repo Market?
summary: It is unclear why Amar Bhide doesn't just simply support rejuvenation of the Fed Funds market, a place where he concedes banks "can successfully access credit without providing collateral.". While aptly noting the importance of market price signals and the bewildering interactions of bank regulation and economic events, Prof. Amar Bhide then confusingly pivots to advocate explicit central bank guarantees of overnight borrowings and a related guarantee fee ("To Make Banks Stable, End, Don't Mend, the Repo Market," op-ed, Oct. 2). It is unclear why he doesn't simply support rejuvenation of the fed-funds market, a place where he concedes banks "can successfully access credit without providing collateral." Finally, Prof. Bhide should note that the central bank of a least one Scandinavian country, Sweden, does use repo and currently has a negative interest rate on repo borrowings.

title: Fed's Kashkari Supports Rate Cuts, But Unsure How Many More Are Needed
summary: Minneapolis Fed leader says 'we should be supporting the economy, not tapping the brakes' with monetary policy. Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis President Neel Kashkari said Monday he is "happy" the U.S. central bank is lowering rates.

title: Your Religion Is Your Object of Ultimate Concern
summary: What becomes obvious is there are no nonreligious people. We are all just devoted to different things.. A better, comprehensive definition of "religion" than suggested in Barton Swaim's review of Melvin Konner's "Believers: Faith in Human Nature," ("The Future, Not Secular," Books, Sept. 28) is that religion is simply "One's Object of Ultimate Concern," posited by theologian Paul Tillich (1886-1965). By Tillich's definition what becomes obvious is there are no nonreligious people. We are all devoted to different things.

title: Honor the Army's Brave Sacrifice at Chosin
summary: The losses of the Army units were horrifying, and their sacrifices bought time for the Marines and for the survival of South Korea.. Your Sept. 28 front-page photograph and caption about the 69th anniversary of the Battle of Chosin Reservoir omitted the losses of Army units ("U.S. Veterans of Korean War Gather to Mark Storied Battle"). I don't minimize the fighting spirit or the valor of the Marines; however, the omission of the losses of Army units is troubling because for so long their valor and losses were ignored and discounted. It reinforces the old and mistaken idea that the units of the Army X Corps, specifically of the 31st and 32nd Infantry, commanded first by Col. Allan MacLean and later by my father, Lt. Col. Don C. Faith Jr., weren't really worth mentioning. For 50 years the conventional storyline was that the Army was there, but it was only the Marines and Koreans who fought well and lost so many. MacLean was taken prisoner, and my father gave his life to bring his units from close to the Yalu in Manchuria south to a rendezvous point where the expected reinforcements were absent. My father was a posthumous recipient of the Medal of Honor for his actions. The losses of the Army units were horrifying, and their sacrifices bought time for the Marines and for the survival of South Korea.

title: Trump Burned the Bridge to Suburban Women
summary: Heather Higgins's "Trump Tries to Win Disaffected Women Back" is utterly delusional.. Heather R. Higgins's "Trump Tries to Win Disaffected Women Back" (op-ed, Oct. 3) is utterly delusional. She claims that President Trump, to win over the critical votes of disaffected suburban women, has begun to listen to their concerns.

title: High New-Car Debt Is the System's Warning Light
summary: If it isn't in our budget, we don't buy it. It isn't worth stressing over; it's just a car.. After reading "Americans Buy Cars With Piles of Debt" (Page One, Oct. 2), I conclude that we aren't teaching young people the basics of finance and how to budget. I consider my family middle-working class. We keep a car 10 years or more, and we buy a car we can afford. We just purchased a new RAV4, and we paid cash because we saved for it. If the vehicle had been over budget, we would have bought a certified, preowned car. Would we like a flashier vehicle? Sure, but it isn't in our budget so we don't buy it. It isn't worth stressing over; it's just a car.

title: 'The Marginal Revolutionaries' Review: Team Liberty
summary: As socialism and central planning captured the allegiance of intellectuals and governments, one group of thinkers argued for free markets and individual freedom.. At the dawn of the 20th century, Vienna was the nerve center of a vast Austro-Hungarian empire that controlled most of central Europe. The city was a haven of baroque splendor and liberal consciousness, a multicultural citadel of wine, women and song. Ironically, it was also the incubator of revolutionary movements that would make the century the bloodiest in human history and bring profound political, social and economic change to vast stretches of the West.

title: Ireland's Privacy Regulator Moves Closer to Decisions in WhatsApp, Twitter Cases
summary: The cases involve compliance with Europe's transparency and breach-notification rules. A top European Union privacy regulator is moving closer to making draft decisions involving Facebook Inc . 's WhatsApp and Twitter Inc. under the bloc's new privacy law.

title: Planned Syria Action Poses Test of Turkey's Allegiances
summary: Ankara seeks to counter armed Kurdish forces that U.S. has backed, deepening cooperation with Russia. ISTANBUL-Turkey's decision to launch a military offensive in northeastern Syria once American troops have withdrawn opens a new front in the eight-year Syrian conflict, testing the country's influence in a volatile Middle East where the U.S. wants a diminished role and Russia a bigger one.

title: France Rocked by Extremist's Counterterror Role
summary: Mickaël Harpon was allowed to continue working in police intelligence despite arguing that the Charlie Hebdo terror attack was justified. summary: Central banker's remarks come amid continued criticism from President Trump.

title: The NBA's Timid Brick in China
summary: A tweet about Hong Kong protests provokes an international incident. It's hard to think of an organization that's enjoyed a run of attention as unabashedly positive as what the NBA has enjoyed over the past half-decade or so. This is the enlightened league that "gets it"; that allows its players and coaches to speak freely on matters both sporting and political; that is currently amid a "player empowerment" era in which it's the talent on the court, not the chair-bound executives, who are largely determining the future of the game.

title: The Latest Eco-Friendly Status Symbol? Water Bottles
summary: As more people lug around reusable water bottles, these sippable containers-from upscale labels like Supreme and Prada-have become envy-inducing accessories. STARTING IN middle school, Megan DeStefano began carrying a water bottle around with her. She was an athlete, and her mother had hammered home the importance of drinking water, but her puzzled peers looked at her askance. "People thought it was weird," said Ms. DeStefano, now 29 and a registered dietician in Temple, Texas. "I was one of the few high schoolers carrying a water bottle with me to class."

title: Coal Baron Robert Murray's Companies Edge Closer to the Brink

summary: Tom Brady passed Brett Favre to be third all time in passing yards. But the NFL's passing boom may mean it's not long before all these records are toppled.. It's a testament to one of the best players ever, his unprecedented durability-Brady is 42 years old, you might have heard-and a career that has already produced six Super Bowl rings.

title: Today's Politics May Be Bad for Your Health
summary: Citizens in a new study blame U.S. politics for stress, depression, lost sleep and other physical and mental problems. A Chicago woman is so uneasy about politics that she has needed two dental implants to deal with her teeth-grinding habit. And a New York woman says she suffered her first flare-up of multiple sclerosis in 10 years due to political angst.

title: A Day in the Life of Architect David Rockwell
summary: From designing Nobu Downtown to creating Broadway sets, the architect's wide-ranging practice involves seeking out each project's narrative thread.. Over the past three and a half decades, David Rockwell and his architecture and design firm, Rockwell Group, have built a reputation for their versatility and prolific output. From vibey hotels to Broadway sets, solemn memorials to grand restaurants, each case is an opportunity to expand their repertoire. "We are obsessively not interested in repeating ourselves," the New York-based architect says. "There's still a sense that every detail matters, even after all these years."

summary: Details that were wrong or omitted from its financial disclosures may have soured investors. The more investors learned about WeWork, the less they liked it. The details that were wrong or omitted from its financial disclosures played a part in weakening investor appetite and will pose risks if the company ever tries to go public again.

title: Going Up? The Elevator-as-a-Service Business
summary: Executives are helping develop new revenue opportunities built around a tech-driven service model. NEW YORK-When passengers step into one of the 36 elevators running at 10 Hudson Yards, the heavy lifting is done by a network of software and sensors.

title: Teens Ignored Vaping Warnings for Years. Now, Some Are Scared.
summary: Resume Subscription. Buffalo, Minn.

title: Corporate CFOs in High Demand at Charities as Budgets Come Under Scrutiny
summary: Transition to the not-for-profit world creates a unique set of challenges, CFOs and recruiters say. After three decades working as a financial executive for General Electric Co. and the Depository Trust & Clearing Corp., Oscar Raposo took a career break in 2015 to go backpacking in Asia. When it was time to return to work, he decided to move into the nonprofit sector.

title: U.S. Troops to Withdraw From Northern Syria Ahead of Turkish Incursion
summary: White House statement followed call between Trump and Erdogan. WASHINGTON-The White House indicated that U.S. forces will withdraw from northern Syria in advance of an expected incursion of Turkish forces in the region that could spark fighting with American-backed Kurds, in what officials believe could be the end of the fight against Islamic State there.

title: The NBA Feels a Backlash in China After a Tweet Supporting Hong Kong
summary: Chinese companies have suspended ties with the Rockets, one of the NBA's most popular teams in China, after Houston's general manager tweeted his support of pro-democracy protests in Hong Kong. The National Basketball Association scrambled late Sunday to contain an escalating crisis in China after a Houston Rockets executive's tweets supporting pro-democracy protests in Hong Kong sparked an international furor.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Wall Street Brokers Missed the Index-Funds Memo
summary: Even as passive investments thrive, big brokers put just 29% of fund assets in them. What's going on?. In recent years, investors have been flocking to low-cost index funds, driven by their long-term record of outperforming higher-cost actively managed funds.

title: Bond Funds Continue to Attract Cash
summary: Money continued to pour in to bond-focused funds in the third quarter, even though stock funds are up 18.3% for the year. Give us our bonds!

title: A Silver Medal...for Stock Picking This Time
summary: Olympic medalist Joe Hudepohl of Eaton Vance shines in manager contest; Akre Focus Fund rides a 20% gain over 12 months to win first. Being a multiple-and repeat-winner isn't a new experience for Joe Hudepohl.

title: October Is the Stock Market's Most-Volatile Month. But Why?
summary: There are plenty of theories, most of which don't really hold up. There appears to be no fundamental reason why October should be the most volatile month of the stock-market calendar. Yet it often is.

title: Beware: You Might Not Be Buying the Stock You Think You Are
summary: Investors who quickly buy or sell a stock in the news can sometimes wind up with the wrong one, a study finds. The next time you buy a stock, you might want to make sure it's the right one for the company you want to invest in.

title: A Value Investor Defends Value Investing (Despite Its Recent Track Record)
summary: Joel Greenblatt says if you do good valuation work, the market eventually will agree. Joel Greenblatt laughs when asked if value investing-the struggling style of money management that he champions-is dead.

title: ETFs Get All the Buzz, but Mutual Funds Still Dominate. There's a Reason.
summary: With $19.87 trillion in assets under management as of June 30, mutual funds are expected to remain a force despite the surging popularity of ETFs. Over the past decade, many experts have predicted that the open-end mutual-fund industry would crumble, an inevitable victim of exchange-traded funds. No less an authority than Morningstar Inc. two years ago dubbed mutual funds' projected slide in assets under management as "flowmaggedon."

title: Investors Rush Into Quality Stocks
summary: Economic uncertainty has pushed investors into stocks that may be better able to withstand a downturn. As uncertainty mounts over the direction of the economy and financial markets, investors are flooding into exchange-traded funds focused on so-called quality stocks.

title: Hedge-Fund Performance Goes From Bad to Less Bad
summary: Hedge-fund returns were much improved over the first half of 2018 compared to the same period last year, but still woefully trail the market. The hedge-fund industry continues to do this year what it has been doing for more than a decade-trailing the stock market big time.

title: Why Morningstar's Changes in Its Rating Systems Could Lower Fund Fees
summary: Gold/silver/bronze medal considerations will be weighed independently for different share classes. Two small changes in Morningstar 's fund-ratings system could continue the trend of downward pressure on the fees investors pay to asset managers and financial advisers.

title: Agriculture ETFs Draw Interest in Uncertain Times
summary: These funds have had a few tough years. But the fact that their returns aren't correlated to stocks and bonds could make them more attractive.. Exchange-traded funds focused on agricultural commodities have had a tough few years. However, the fact that their returns are largely uncorrelated to stocks and bonds could make them more attractive, especially if the economic outlook darkens.

title: Brexit Jitters Trigger ETF Outflows
summary: Investors took a net $405 million out of Vanguard FTSE Europe ETF in September. (VGK) absorbed net outflows of $405 million in September amid continuing political turmoil in the U.K. as the government wrestled with how to leave the European Union.

title: An ETF That Stays on Brand
summary: Brand Value ETF aims to identify companies with a strong brand value that isn't recognized in their share price. For investors, brand power is an undervalued asset.

title: What Is 'Economic Shock'?
summary: To qualify as an economic shock, an event needs to have a major economic impact-and be a surprise. When the price of oil jumped 15% in a single weekend last month, some analysts started using the term "economic shock." What does that mean, and how is it relevant to investors now?

title: Portugal's Ruling Socialists Lead in Elections
summary: Prime Minister Costa's party falls short of absolute majority needed and will have to seek support of other far-left parties. Socialist Prime Minister António Costa, who has presided over one of the eurozone's brightest success stories, came in first in national elections Sunday but failed to win an outright majority.

title: Attorneys for CIA Officer Behind Trump Complaint Say They Now Represent 'Multiple Whistleblowers'
summary: One attorney said a second whistleblower has come foward with firsthand knowledge of some of the allegations. WASHINGTON-At least one additional whistleblower with firsthand knowledge of the circumstances around President Trump's July call with his Ukrainian counterpart has come forward, according to lawyers representing both the individual and the CIA officer whose initial complaint helped spark an impeachment inquiry.
